I am not sure if this is the best way I could tell my story. I really like the thought of using flashbacks in my comic. Not to just fill in spots but as a way to really tell the story. I am just not sure how others would react to that type of
storytelling.
What do you guys think?
#1 Shows don't tell
Show*
Very helpful...
As long as it wasn’t dependent, why not
What do you think Tom? Can a structured use of flashbacks make for good storytelling?
Dependent?
Flashbacks are the lazy way to tell something if they pop up with no reasons other than expositions. The story should naturally flows towards it.
It is not exposition. It is a clever way to tell the story. Purposely holding back bits of information to add tension that would reveal themselves in a flashback at an opportune moment.
For example, you are following the protagonist in the present but discover their experiences that drive their motivations through flashbacks.
As the present moves forward so do the flashbacks, kinda of like following the protagonist but in two timelines.
I am getting some ideas...
I like it...
Hi
Hello Rima.
Sup
Just talking, was trying to see others opinion about using flashbacks as an element of the story above.
I can’t look I’m driving plus on phone
Hm...
Not driving now so what’s up
Just trying to determine if what I think would be a great story telling tool would be something others would find interesting when reading. I would like to use flashbacks actively.
I will paste the example I wrote earlier.
For example, you are following the protagonist in the present but discover their experiences that drive their motivations through flashbacks.
As the present moves forward so do the flashbacks, kinda of like following the protagonist but in two timelines.
I'm with Azuma. Flashbacks are something to use very sparingly.
used*
In Medias Res, it's called
Can be good if done right, but over-reliance can hurt the plot
I am not using flashbacks to dump information on the reader.
When they're used overmuch, it just feels like "Oh, the author didn't plan this character's character this far ahead, so they're just adding information to make it fit."
It is essentially two stories on the same character at different times.
But the other story is necessary to understand the character in the main plot
Ergo, information dump
"Oh, another flashback to try to make me feel for somthing that's only just now getting established." It's very droll
I am not coming at it that way though Dadro. My am coming in knowing the full extent of the flashbacks.
Then it's just pointless filler no?
It would not even come close to appearing or reading that way.
It is not pointless filler, it serves a very important purpose...
Earlier you said it would be done to "hold information back" and now it's "known to the full extent"
It's either/or. What your hypothesizing is called "trying to have your cake and eat it too."

Okay, so if I never had any flashbacks and started the comic from the beginning of the first flashback, it would be just a normal story arch that progresses forward. There would be two climaxes, one in the middle and one at the end, then end being larger.
Sounds like a fairly stock standard story.
As I said before, In Media Res CAN work. But usually only once
What I want to do is splice the two climaxes together, so two stories at different times happening together. They naturally feed eachother.
Like, if you have to have a flashback segment, then only have ONE flashback segment
How shall I say this.... Good fucking luck maybe?
How many pages do you have officially written and completed?
Would such a thing be really that bad to read?
Actually, probably yes.
yes
Oh, no pages written. I am conceptualizing my story. This flashback thing has been the backbone of how I wanted to tell the story.
I have lore and characters and stuff, but I have not committed to anything.
If the pages alternate then it could get confusing for the average viewer. I suppose if each page was itself split between present and past with a clear divider then it could work
But if done poorly it could also be an assault on the eyes

Having the reader swapping back and forth their focuses on two distantly related stories lessens the focus you'd have on both individually that I don't think even a potentially fantastical climax could assuage.
A flashback and present would be multiple pages if not quite a few pages long and would be obvious which is which.
Why not just make them two separate comics and update them simultaneously?
The finale climax ties in the flashback climax.
Then link them at that point. They don't have to be together to be connected. Look at Marvel or DC
They are following the same protagonist.
Or make them one after the other chronologically? Like a normal comic?
Or a normal story for that matter.
I could do that, but I rather liked that idea of telling the story differently than everyone else.
Sounds like you need to brush up on your Hero's Journey. Not a chance you read the book I proffered a few nights ago?
The problem is sometimes an idea isn't done because it's hard to put into practice, not because nobody's thought of it
Both of you are really against flashbacks altogether as if they are the devil or something.
Dude I repeatedly said it can work. Just not in the way you want.
I can stop being polite about this if you want
Literally said the exact opposite. "Flashbacks are something to use very sparingly."
What you said was to throw my idea into the garbage and only have one flashback.
Because it won't work well
Some things aren't done because they're just not a good approach
Your idea, for instance, has an extreme danger of being confusing and convoluted as the plots progress
You'd need to have a clear marker to separate the two, but that would defeat the purpose
To say nothing of the fact that you haven't even tried it yet, and yet you're betting on it completely and utterly.
See, anything that I would say that would make it obvious one was a flashback over the other would be a spoiler to the story.
Therein lies the issue
Ideas can be fun. But execution is everything.
If you have two separate plots but don't differentiate them, then how is the reader going to know which is which?
I am not betting everything on it, but I have been working from this viewpoint for a while and it seems like a very good way to tell the story I created.
Well, we're not stopping you from trying it out. Just offering some constructive criticism
No, I cannot tell YOU what would differentiate them because that would be a spoiler. It is right there in the comic the entire time and obvious to the reader.
